Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: A poll worker requests that the voter re-sign a smudged envelope so the ballot will not risk rejection later.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, ballot in hand, ready to mail it in before work. My mom came in, her eyes red, and sat across from me. She started talking about how lonely she’d been feeling since Dad’s health started declining. She needed me to listen, to reassure her, to just be there. I wanted to reach out, to hold her hand, but my phone buzzed—a reminder to drop off my ballot before the post office closed. I remembered the poll worker’s instructions: if the signature was smudged, I had to re-sign the envelope or my vote might not count. I looked down and saw the ink had blurred. My mom’s voice trembled as she spoke, and I could see how much she needed me. But the ballot in my hand felt heavy with responsibility, too. I was torn, feeling the weight of my mother’s pain and the civic duty pressing on me at the same time, unsure which role to answer first.
